title: Abū Sulaymān al-Dārānī
content: Abū Sulaymān al-Dārānī , ʿAbd al-Raḥmān b. Aḥmad b. ʿAṭiyya al-ʿAnasī al-Dārānī, was a Sufi sage of the 2nd–3rd/8th–9th century. Some called him ʿAbd al-Raḥmān b. ʿAṭiyya, associating him with his grandfather (al-Sulamī, 68; Anṣārī, 39). He was called al-ʿAnasī due to his connection with the Banū ʿAnas b. Mālik, a tribe from Yemen (al-Samʿānī, 9/395; Ibn Khallikān, 3/131). He was born around 140/757 (al-Dhahabī, 10/182). He was born in a village in Damascus called Dāriyā (al-Khawlānī, 107; al-Sulamī, 68; Abū Nuʿaym, 9/254), and hence he was known as al-Dārānī, even though this nisba is contrary to the grammatical rules of Arabic (al-Yāfiʿī, Mirʾāt , 2/30; Yāqūt, 2/536; Ibn Khallikān, 3/131). Some have claimed that he was originally from Wāsiṭ in Iraq but lived in Damascus (Ibn Abī Ḥātim, 2(2)/214; Yāqūt, 2/536; Ibn ʿAsākir, 9/823).

Abū Sulaymān narrated ḥadīth s from ʿAbd al-Wāḥid b. Zayd, Sufyān al-Thawrī, Rabīʿ b. Ṣabīḥ and others from Iraq (Ibn Abī Ḥātim, 2(2)/214; al-Sulamī, 69; al-Samʿānī, 5/271; Ibn ʿAsākir, 9/823; al-Dhahabī, 10/182) and he is said to have corresponded with Abū Yazīd al-Basṭāmī (Maybudī, 6/91). His contemporaries included Abū Jaʿfar b. al-Farajī and Maʿrūf al-Karkhī, who was also his companion (see al-Sulamī, 78; Anṣārī, 247). Among his family, his brother Dāwūd b. Aḥmad (ʿAyn al-Quḍāt, 24; Jāmī, 36; Ibn al-Mulaqqin, 393) and his son Sulaymān (Anṣārī, 40; Yāqūt, 2/536) became eminent Sufi masters of Syria.
Those who narrated his ḥadīth s included Aḥmad b. Abī al-Ḥawārī, Ḥumayd b. Hishām al-ʿAnasī and ʿAbd al-Raḥīm b. Ṣāliḥ (al-Sulamī, 68; al-Khawlānī, 110, 112; al-Samʿānī, 5/271; al-Dhahabī, 10/182).

Abū Sulaymān seems to have travelled to Iraq in order to hear ḥadīth s (Yāqūt, 2/536; al-Samʿānī, 5/271). He stayed for a time in Baghdad during one of his journeys which took place around 203/818 (al-Khaṭīb, 10/248; Ibn ʿAsākir, 9/825). It is said that in Iraq he was more of a pious worshipper ( ʿābid ), while in Syria he was more like a gnostic sage ( ʿārif ) (Anṣārī, 40; al-Khaṭīb, 10/249; Ibn al-Jawzī, Ṣifa , 4/224). He also travelled to Mecca (Ibn Abī Ḥātim, 2(2)/214; al-Yāfiʿī, Rawḍ al-rayāḥīn , 142, 444). There are also reports that because Abū Sulaymān claimed he could see angels and converse with them, the inhabitants of Damascus expelled him from the city but later allowed him to return (Ibn ʿAsākir, 9/841; Ibn Shākir, 7/224; Ibn Kathīr, 10/270).

There are differing opinions as to the date of his death, ranging from 204–235/819–850 (see Ibn ʿAsākir, 9/842; Ibn Kathīr, 10/270). He was buried in the village of Dāriyā, and a tomb was built over his grave. He also left some endowment properties (Ibn Kathīr, 10/270). His tomb was well known in Yāqūt's time (Yāqūt, 2/536).

Abū Sulaymān's Sufi disciplines were in complete conformity with the Qurʾān and the sunna , and he refused to accept any ideas or actions unless they were in accordance with both of them (al-Sarrāj, 104; al-Sulamī, 70; al-Qushayrī, Tarjuma , 41; Ibn Kathīr, 10/267). He ate little, and such were his ascetic practices that he was given the title Bundār al-jāʾiʿīn (‘lord of the hungry’) (al-Mustamlī al-Bukhārī, 1/207; ʿAṭṭār, 276). According to him, jūʿ (hunger) is one of the jewels from the treasury of God, and is bestowed only upon true lovers (al-Sarrāj, 202; al-Khaṭīb, 10/250; see also Abū Nuʿaym, 9/259; al-Qushayrī, al-Risāla , 142; Ibn ʿAsākir, 9/827). He was deemed to be a master of the spiritual science of waqt (time); in this context, he considered it necessary that khawf (fear) and rajāʾ (hope) should be kept in balance, saying, according to Hujwīrī: ‘If hope predominates over fear, one's “time” is spoilt because “time” is the preservation of one's state ( ḥāl ), which is preserved only so long as one is possessed by fear. If on the other hand fear predominates over hope, belief in unity ( tawḥīd ) is lost inasmuch as excessive fear springs from despair and despair of God is polytheism ( shirk ). Accordingly, the maintenance of belief in unity con-sists in right hope, and the maintenance of “time” in right fear, and both are maintained when hope and fear are equal’ (al-Hujwīrī, 139 [Nicholson tr. 112–113]; al-Sulamī, 69; al-Qushayrī, al-Risāla , 127–128). Abandonment of the world and its demands is the condition for reaching perfection, and anything that occupies man's attention takes him far from God. Therefore, all those who seek a livelihood or wish for a wife or are engaged in the recording of ḥadīth s are in fact desirous of the world (Abū Ṭālib, 1/319; al-Ghazālī, 2/443; al-Suhrawardī, 86; Ibn al-Jawzī, Talbīs , 209). Abū Sulaymān had a low opinion of building families or having children, saying that those who want children are ignorant, since they keep man away from the worship of God (Ibn al-Jawzī, Talbīs , 210). He also said that a heart filled with love of this world is empty of love for the Hereafter (al-Sulamī, 70; al-Qushayrī, al-Risāla , 411).

According to al-Dārānī, the stations ( maqāmāt ) on the spiritual path are of three kinds: renunciation ( zuhd ), abstinence ( waraʿ ) and contentment ( riḍāʾ ) (Abū Ṭālib, 2/87), and the behaviour of one travelling the path should be based upon four pillars: fear, hope, veneration ( taʿẓīm ) and contrition ( ḥayāʾ ) (al-Suhrawardī, 189; al-Kāshānī, 421). Abū Sulaymān was not particularly in favour of samāʿ (Sufi ‘audition’ or mystical concert), saying that anyone who is deeply moved by a pleasant melody has a weak heart that needs curing. Such a person is like a child who is put to sleep by a sweet song (al-Qushayrī, al-Risāla , 348; Ibn al-Mulaqqin, 387). According to him, that which is not already in the heart cannot be found through samāʿ (al-Bākharzī, 2/185).
